reviews.review_msg: Solid choice for CMPT 363. Assignments and tests as well as their markings was fair for the course content.
One of the better professors at SFU. Lectures were a bit boring at times but were usually engaging. Assignments were good and fair. Exams were fair. No major complaints, you can do a lot worse.

Needlessly over-complicated course materials with no bearing on practical interface design, marks get docked randomly for things not on the rubric, and going to lectures is completely useless as they cover nothing that isn't just on the slides. Easy enough in hindsight, but needlessly stressful, arbitrary, useless, and (worst of all) boring.

very boring, can't even complete a sentence without stuttering, really really specific with his grading and takes away marks for tiny mistakes, doesn't have interest in his own content, and did i say very boring? but he's a really nice guy

Worst cs prof I ever had. She literally reads text book out word by word.  This course is highly subjective, I asked her why I got 0 on one of my midterm question but someone else got full mark with essentially the same answer as mine. She answered, "there was nothing wrong with your answer, I just don't like your answer." argh...

Anne is clueless as to how things are done in the work place today. She has an attitude problem if you contest the classroom material being taught. The other students don't know any better, but for people who actually work in the field the stuff she is preaching is at least 15 years out of date. Avoid her if you would like to learn relevant work.

Not bad. Too theoretical, you won't be coding alot in this class. She has a nice attitude and genuinely wants to help. For assignments, ask for clarification (might get docked marks for silly things).

Fun/interesting prof, although he was unorganized at times. It was also annoying to not have a textbook, not very used to HAVING to attend lectures and take notes these days. I actually feel like I learned some very important principles pertaining to user interfaces - but for the amount of content in this course,it could have been taught in a month
Great lectures, no textbook needed.
nice guy, easy course

unbelievable! how can students recommend this lecturer for this course? Yes, he may be intrested in the course, but he lacks ability to transfer knowledge: unprepared & boring lectures, difficult exams on easy content; taking this course with him is a GREAT mistake for a serious student cos it does not matter if you work hard or not.Take my advice!

This prof is poorly organized. More than a couple of times he showed up to lecture saying "there's no lecture 'cause I haven't prepared". Assts and tests are given back very slowly (got first assignment more than halfway into the semester). Marking seems random and he can't even explain what's going to be on the test.
there have to be better than this guy for this course

went to class once every other week just studied notes from first 2 weeks and got an A. hes boring to listen to very repetetive not prepared, and his example lack imaginaiton. whole course spent criticizing websites. lame but good for those who need gpa boost they give him lot of good reviews here!

This was the easiest course I've ever taken at SFU.  But mostly that was because I was already pretty interested in interface design and Ted's passion for the subject made me even more interested.  If you're going to take this class you couldn't find anyone better to teach it.

Glad I didn't take a REAL cmpt course with this guy, he's very low on talent - not even close to the esteem of other profs.  I dreaded every moment of class with him because he just doesn't seem to say anything of meaning.  The course was very easy but unfairly marked.  Work hard or don't work at all and you'll still get the same grade.

He makes sure you really understand concepts through assignments that make you apply things you've learnt in class. This is not a course where you memorise and spit out. It's one you digest. His style of teaching may not be pleasing to some because he seems scattered at times, but he sure bent on you learning!

This class is mostly writing and a lot of imagination.  No programming... if you can write a decent essay then you shouldn't have problems in this class.  Textbook is boring... prof makes it a bit more interesting with real world examples and an interesting group project.

Sometimes unorganized, but a good prof. Lots of in-class practise, which is the best way to learn this material (practice, review, evaluate eachothers' work). Nice guy, great UI anecdotes. Always concerned about the 'UI' of the classroom! ("Can you see that there? Is that too bright/blurry/dark/small?") :)
Gotta be the worst class in Cmpt Sci.
Gotta be the easiest class in Cmpt Sci

Paul is the most approachable professor I have ever met. You can even find him any time after class. All assignments are closely related to the course, and you need to understand the course content and assignment requirements, writing skills are also required.attend all classes. you will get a high score because the grading is very clear.

Paul is a great person, however, the course itself is subjective. It's hard to know if you're on the right track or even remotely doing the right thing. Paul is very accessible however and truly seems to care. It would be nice if this course was more objective than subjective, but I guess with the nature of the material that would be hard.

I was baited by the reviews to take this course, but be warned that you don't learn anything useful related to UI/UX design since everything that is taught is very basic and intuitive. This course is a huge time sink with no reward, assignments are mind-numbing and tedious, and weekly readings eat up time that I'd rather spend on other courses.

The teacher is very responsible, very quick to answer questions, and the materials needed to provide in class are also very thoughtful. The course content was also interesting, although I felt that the excessive writing assignments and the grading of the written assignments made it difficult to improve the grades

I have mixed feelings about this course. The content is very interesting and Paul is a good instructor, but his grading is heavily based on writing skills which I don't have. Also, there are not many opportunities to practice ui design hands-on before the group project. Will not recommend if you care about GPA and are not good at writing.

Gonna do weekly readings and summarize them. Lectures are optional, but I shown up to them anyways. Have to write a exam question each week which I was terrible at so YMMV Subjective grading for projects but it is UX so uhh yeah Overall, great course. Learnt lots about new things.
Very good professor. Read the weakly readings and you wont have to study for the final. Very easy course but requires a lot of your weekly time. I recommend taking 363 with him.

CMPT 363 (online) requires constant, but low-stress effort. You have weekly readings, which are surprisingly helpful, and make up most of the content of the course. You have enough time for the group projects, so doing a little bit every other day is an easy way to get a good mark. Getting Paul's feedback is essential for improving your marks.

Paul Hibbitts is one of the best professors I have had. This man is passionate about UX design, and applies it to every aspect of the course. He makes sure the course is interesting, he helps you in every way possible, and he asks for feedback and applied it to make sure the course is perfect. Really an amazing prof and a treat to have.

Great prof, provides good feedback and all the resources you will need to do good on his assignments and final exam. He also acts on the feedback he is given unlike other profs where it feels like you're sending your feedback straight into the trash.

Paul is one of the best CMPT professors at SFU, he gives really good feedback and makes sure you never make the same mistake twice. Other than that, he is also very clear in his lectures and his grading, the final exam also consists of student generated answers. The course overall was very fun with paul

This is how all courses should be taught. We were actually graded on our ability to think critically about a problem - rather than your ability to regurgitate information - something most SFU CS profs love to test.... In some ways I think this course should almost have a writing designation though, as you will spend a lot of time reading/writing.

Unclear grading criteria and mark assignments subjectively on what he thinks right. If you have a bad grammar, dont take it. His grading is just does not make sense. He grades based on grammar and how the answer is easy for him to understand. He does not care about his international students who have bad grammar but understands the topic.

Paul is great, he is really interested in getting student feedback on things to improve and actually applies the feedback quickly. This course with him feels like you learn useful things you can actually apply in the field. No midterms just two group projects and a final exam that comes from student weekly questions.
Tough grader, avoid at all cost. Dont have high hope on him, you wont get 90-100 on your assignment. Hard to get an A.

This teacher just wants to be respected. He does NOT LISTEN to the students opinions and mark assignments based on what he and his TA is right. He does not care about you students! UX cant be marked based on one or two person who are experienced. It just doesnt go like that sir.

Look guys, Paul is very tough in grading and so his TA's. The course seems easy but the teacher just made it tough. I do not recommend this teacher if you are looking for GPA. He is just not good at grading. His grading scheme just does not make sense for the assignments and quizzes. He makes you read every week and create questions for his final.
Paul is definitely the best prof I have ever met in my SFU life. Take this course, go to lecture, I guarantee you will change your perspective on UX design completely

Paul is honestly one of the best profs at SFU. Talking to him was like talking to a friend. Asking him for help was always super easy because he usually responds on the Canvas discussion board. If anyone is interested in Cmpt 363 or needs extra credits. Paul's class is honestly the best choice.

Paul is one of the best professors at SFU. He not only lectures, but also actively works in the industry. He has a highly modern teaching style & seems to genuinely care about his students. He is polite, professional & is always available. All readings are (free) online, group project is big but allows you to pick your own groups & grade your peers
He is one of the best Professor at SFU. Recommend!
Don't be creativity if you want to get good marks, just follow rules, laws and theorems that he gave in the class.

He marked assignments and test subjectively. He likes out dated concept from textbook and disagrees creative designs. Even you spend a lot of time on doing "REAL" user research and design a "REAL" UI that SFU students really need. He will still give you low marks due to his personal point of view. Avoid this class if you do want to be creative.
Paul's one of the best instructors who has ever taught me. He's very nice and kind to students; quite helpful too. You won't regret taking his course.

One of the best professors at SFU. Always available and eager to help out (has at least 3 ways of reaching him at any time). Helps student understand the material in depth, and is always good to stop by and chat if he has office hours. SFU needs more professors like him!

Every lecture with Hibbitts will blow your mind. The material is interesting, well organized, and teaches you valuable skills. If you can show you understand the material, even if you do bad on assignments or the midterm, you can still get an A in this course. Paul Hibbitts is a god amongst men! Do not miss your chance to take this course with him.

A++ prof. Take Paul if you want to learn excellent user centered design. SIAT students should also take this course as you learn a lot more then in other IAT courses. Assignments and marking is beyond fair and you really get  to use everything that you have learned in class for the three group assignments.

Opposite to the common belief, I didn't find the marking to this course subjective. It's just a matter of learning certain concepts and applying them on practice. Very helpful prof and very interesting lectures.

I enjoyed almost every class. He knows what he's talking about, and directly linked it to real world examples. The course yields an easier work-load, which is not Paul's fault. He did a great job teaching the material. I have heard he can be non-helpful to some people though. Can't win em all.

Shows great understanding of the material (especially thru his lectures). Assignments are very well-related and requires the student to do a little more than usual. Midterm and final exam are subjective and requires you to really know your stuff. Overall, a great course and a great prof. (BEST ONE!)
Best Prof Ever!!!

very good teacher keeps the class interesting. very good "applied" techniques. all you whiners .... well you're whiners! its a design course so DUH its subjective! he says it in the first class! u dont like it BUH-BYE

Of course the marking is subjective, it's a freaking design class. Anyways, the class was great and Hibbitts is an excellent prof. Keeps the class dynamic, interactive, and very interesting. Great course, great prof, and not too hard to boot.
Work load is very little, but study load is a lot. The tests are pretty easy if u study
This guy does know his stuff. Fair-ish tests ...

One of the fakest prof that i know at this school. Act as if he cares about the students but all he cares about is good eval to keep his comfy/easy job, once eval is done, he won't help.  Assignments and test are marked subjectively.
Interesting lectures but his tests rely too much on memorization. especially in the midterm. Marking on homework unpredictable.
Absolutely amazing! He really knows his stuff & has REAL-WORLD non-academic exp!
Great prof, kind of iffy marking but extremely intersting teaching
Dynamic lectures
Very good prof, and knows the stuff well
take him if u wanna learn good UI design
No Comments
Great prof, no textbook, clear notes and lectures

He wants you to be as specific as possible in all assignments and exams. He is a tough grader. I took it with doing 263 so it was a high learning curve for me. He is good at explaining and clarifying the doubts.
Yeah, even though there are gradings criteria, its still unclear af. Avoid at all cost..

Please avoid Victor AT ALL COST, even for easy classes. Every time I have him, he makes it 100x harder than it needs to be. He loveeees to provoke the class after exams for having bad marks when he's the one finding every way possible to reduce our grades to ashes. His lectures are also boring and he still blames the class for not coming.

final grade 78% for C+ in this course. For the very heavy project, you should learn UI/UX tools by yourself. The project is 85 pts totally we got 78(which is a high grade in class)but minus 5 directly with the late 10 mins contribution form.  Very rule-oriented and even strict.
Very group project heavy especially since the groups are around 4-5 members each.

This class has a very high workload so make sure your schedule only consists of 1 or 2 computer classes. The group project is heavy and you need to know friends in the class in order to not have issues later down the road regarding who does what. The curve is big so know that your A will become a B and your B will become a C.

One of the worst profs I've had at SFU. Yes the class is easy because he gives everyone an A on every assignment and project until the very end. He then assign very low grades to the whole class to bring down the average for no good reason. You will get at least a B doing nothing in the class. If you want anything higher it will be mostly luck.

Victor makes learning easier and enjoyable. He encourages discussions and explains concepts clearly. His lecture slides are descriptive too. Even though classes were returned to in person, he's been streaming every lecture on Zoom as well as uploading the recording. He's organized and communicates well so there's no surprises. He actually cares.

Professor Cheung is a super wholesome, he is genuinely interested in UX/UI design interface, he specializes in HCI. Even with the lecture being online, he does his best to keep the class engaged. He really cares about his students and shows interest in students' work. Great professor and super organized!

Overall, decent class. Fairly organized, very group project heavy. If you can, have some friends that you trust take this course with you so you don't get randoms. Assignments, projects were marked tough b/c of TA, depends on who you get. Final was very straightforward open book MC with short answers. Lower rating b/c of TA inconsistent grading.

Decent class and group project. Taught interesting content, and made a 3-hour evening class enjoyable. The marking criteria for the group project are not very clear. Final exam is a good difficulty and covers the entire course.

Very arrogant and shows little respect for students time. Is always late to class and spent more time talking about his own projects/awards because his lecture slides are a mess. Any questions asked are dismissed with more questions from him. His idea of studying is read everything over again, but tests are fairly easy. Won't learn anything, avoid.

He asks you to choose what to do for the project, but he has specific project topics he prefers. Lectures were pretty boring, and he didn't teach the material very well, although the midterm/final wasn't that hard. tldr - not very good at teaching, only take this course with him if you want to work on a project cmpt275-style.

This course is suppose to be easy, but he made it like 275, and was very tedious and not very helpful.  I'll take it with another prof is I were you.  The class can easily fail, and require more work than necessary. I wonder why he's still teaching.  Breaks my self-esteem when I ask a question, make me look stupid every time. :(

Very easy course, and Stella makes it that much easier. The projects were very straight forward, the presentation at the end was really easy, and the midterms were pretty standard. You've got to study off of the notes, and you'll do fine. Got an A+ and I attended half the lectures. Just study the slides and notes, and you'll be fine.

Overall a pretty easy course.  I managed to get an A in this class which is rare for me considering that I am not a smart student and pretty lazy.  Exams are pretty easy, read through her lecture notes and you'll easily get a decent grade.  Would definitely take another course with her if I got the opportunity.
A very easy class.  Unfortunately, it is also tediously boring.  Stella does her best to make it interesting.  Her grading is fair, the workload is light, and the usefulness is rather limited.

Course involves a semester-long group project, so beware of deadweight group members. Slept through 90% of lectures and still managed to get an A. Assignments are generally fair (though difficulty may depend on what your group decides to for the project), exams are also very fair. Grades participation based on class activity handout sheets.

Very good professor who makes a boring class a bit more interesting.  She is definitely interested in the material and overall it is a an easy class.  It is true for an HCI professor she seems to have problems using her computer.  Would take a class with her again.

I had an enjoyable time with her for summer 2007 intersession, but too bad it wasn't full semester. Tries to keep lecs interesting, and admits she's like all of us who aren't experts in all user interfaces. That's how we learn and improve. Manageable tests and asns and fairly marked. More importantly they reflect what we learned in class and text.

Very easy course and she's a good prof, minus her inability to use exactly what she's teaching (i.e. interfaces)  Some things are annoying about her but marking is fair and class expectations are more than fair - at least for this course which was a breeze.  The notes are decent, and lectures aren't all that boring.
Simple class, with not a whole lot of work required.  I'd say it's a pretty easy credit.
exams are incredibly easy, lots of assignments but none take much work. easy credit and somewhat interesting.
one of the easiest courses I've taken in sfu. It shows that she's not an expert in UI design and HCI. But what the heck, Ive taken it because its a gpa booster, cant complain

First time teaching this course.  Basically summarizes the recommended text and present them to us.  Good research background, but comments regarding HCI made in class are too subjective.  This is a theory class; not an art class.  A lot of overlap with CMPT 275.  A lot of work required; be prepared.
No Comments
